official-title.#text: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase the excise tax on gasoline, diesel, and kerosene fuels.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Update, Promote, and Develop America’s Transportation Essentials Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The
Since the passage of SAFETEA–LU, Congress has transferred over $50 billion from the General Fund to the Highway Trust Fund, in order to maintain solvency.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: estimates after the end of Fiscal year 2014, annual General Fund transfers of approximately $15 billion will be necessary in order to maintain current Highway Trust Fund spending levels.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: also estimates that in order to provide funding for surface transportation projects where the Federal benefit outweighs the cost, an additional $83 billion a year would need to be allocated to the Highway and Transit Trust Funds.

text.#text: The

The American Society for Civil Engineers estimates that in order to meet our economic and transportation needs, the United States should invest at least an additional $500 billion in our surface transportation system by 2020.

term.#tail: plan, includes a recommendation to raise the gas tax by fifteen cents.

text.#text: The National Commission on Fiscal Reform and Responsibility report, often referred to as the

The National Surface Transportation Infrastructure Financing Commission recommended, in their 2009 report, that Congress take action to prevent the Highway Trust Fund from becoming insolvent, and to avoid any reductions in infrastructure spending. The Commission also noted that a Federal funding system based on a vehicle miles traveled system, is the consensus choice for the future.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that by 2024 the gas tax should be repealed and replaced with a more sustainable, stable funding source.

text.#text: It is the sense of

header.#text: Sense of Congress regarding replacement of gas tax

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended to read as follows:

external-xref.#tail: of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

text.#text: in the case of gasoline other than aviation gasoline—
for tax imposed before 2014, 18.3 cents per gallon,
for tax imposed during 2014, 26.3 cents per gallon,
for tax imposed during 2015, 30.3 cents per gallon, and
for tax imposed after 2015 and before 2025, 33.3 cents per gallon,

external-xref.#tail: of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

text.#text: in the case of diesel fuel or kerosene—
for tax imposed before 2014, 24.3 cents per gallon,
for tax imposed during 2014, 32.3 cents per gallon,
for tax imposed during 2015, 36.3 cents per gallon, and
for tax imposed after 2015 and before 2025, 39.3 cents per gallon,
